reviewText: Right up front, I'll note that I'm not a dyed-in-the-wool purist when it comes to adapting books into movies.  Sometimes elements in the plot of a book just won't cut it on the big screen, and adjustments need to be made.  Case in point:  I had few problems with Peter Jackson's treatment of my childhood favorite, "The Lord of The Rings".So what am I to think of these Narnia movies, based on my other childhood favorite books?The first movie, "The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe", was pretty faithful to the book, so I had few complaints.  There was no way "Prince Caspian" could have been filmed as it was written, but that whole pointless attack on Lord Miraz's castle really had me scratching my head.  Still, I liked "Prince Caspian" and saw it twice in the theater.As for the third film, "Voyage of The Dawn Treader", it departs from the book in a number of significant ways.  Sometimes this is good, sometimes not so good.------------------------Since I consider "Dawn Treader" to be an OK movie, let me start with the numerous things I liked.What I really loved about the "Dawn Treader" book was its sense of adventure, an epic voyage into the great unknown.  It was always my favorite of the series.  Edmund and Lucy Pevensie, along with their incredibly geeky and obnoxious cousin, Eustace Clarence Scrubb, fall into a suddenly animated picture of a Narnian sea vessel, only to find themselves actually treading water in the Narnian universe.  They are rescued from drowning by King Caspian, and are taken on board his marvelous little ship.Having secured his kingdom, Caspian is on a voyage of discovery into the East.  His primary mission is to discover the fate of seven Telmarine lords of Narnia who were friends of his father, but were exiled by usurper King Miraz.  Along with Caspian is Reepicheep, a talking mouse who is fulfilling his own destiny, prophesied since he was an infant.Throughout the story, our favorite characters learn something about themselves while landing on fantastic new islands and, occasionally, escaping potentially deadly traps.  Eustace at one point is literally transformed.  Lucy has to learn how to confront her envy of her big sister, Susan.  Caspian, as king, must understand that he can't always please himself.  Edmund is just Edmund, kind of an anchor for the others.  He's grown a lot since the first book.Will Poulter, the actor who plays Eustace in the film, is absolutely brilliant -- he nailed the character perfectly.  I have no complaints there.  Lucy was always my favorite Narnia character, and Georgie Henley does a fine job with her.  Ben Barnes plays a good Caspian -- and good riddance to that goofy Spanish accent he had in the last movie.I liked Reepicheep as well.  Perfectly believable, and not the least bit "cutesy" as in the previous film.  I really could believe in his essential nobility, a mouse with the heart of a lion.I also enjoyed the way the movie handled the conflict between Eustace and Reepicheep.  It was much more good-natured than in the book, and more playful.In the movie, Edmund has been given his own set of issues he has to deal with, and his own growing to do.  It's not easy being a king for years, then suddenly being stuffed back into the body of a kid who isn't even old enough to fight for his own king and country in World War II.  So I'll accept the movie's treatment of him as well.For a two-hour film, the islands as described in the book are too many, so some are combined.  Fair enough.I can see the logic in the transformation of Eustace lasting longer than in the book, so as to spread it out over more islands.  Eustace gets a better chance to prove his own worth that way.The music, by David Arnold, is very pleasant.  I've known about him since the movie "Stargate", and the "Dawn Treader" theme melody is still going through my mind as I write this.  It works for the film.The effects are perfectly serviceable.  Long gone are the days when a flying dragon or a talking beast would have looked impossibly cheesy.  I saw the film in 3D, but suspect the 2D experience would have been just as satisfying -- and considerably easier on my pocketbook.A nice touch:  During the end credits, they showed a number of Pauline Baynes' classic drawings from the book.------------------------And now, on to a few aspects of the movie that I'm not so wild about.A major point of departure between the book and the movie comes early on, when our heroes get to the Lone Islands.  As in the book, they get captured by slavers.  Very much unlike in the book, some of these unfortunate slaves are being sacrificed to a mysterious green mist which is threatening to take over the world.Huh???It gets odder.  It turns out that, for some mysterious reason, our heroes find themselves on a quest to collect seven ancient swords and deliver them to Aslan's Table on Ramandu's Island.  If they fail, the whole world will go into the proverbial tank.  And then there's the scary dark island, like a festering sore on the map of the ocean, Ground Zero for all the nastiness seeping into the world.My problem with all this?  It isn't very well explained.  How could it be?  There just isn't enough time.  It feels contrived.I can accept departures from the book when they make sense, but I can't make much sense of the green mist and the seven swords.  It's like a connect-the-dots sort of puzzle, a rote exercise rather than a voyage of discovery.  It vaguely reminds me of a video game I once played.  Green Myst, or something.  But without the interesting puzzles.The bit with the Dufflepuds on Coriakin's island seems very muddled and rushed.Somehow, I've concluded after much thought, the filmmakers had to get Lucy inside Coriakin's house.  There, she would face a very serious test to her integrity, when she starts meddling with things she perhaps ought to leave alone.  Coriakin, the magician, also has to give our heroes some vital information.So, the film couldn't just leave the island out, but then the Dufflepuds didn't really seem to belong, either.  Rather than being kind of funny and even likeable, they end up being a throwaway plot device.  Maybe the film should have dispensed with them altogether.  Coriakin could have met the voyagers on the beach instead.  He has a problem, he tells them, and needs Lucy's help.Caspian's own major character test comes almost as an afterthought, at the very end of the movie, and has little drama.  And, wasn't there supposed to be something important about Ramandu's daughter?  If they ever film "The Silver Chair", this part might become relevant.All in all, the movie was over too quickly.  It's noteworthy that it is the shortest installment of the trilogy.Oh, well.  I'm hoping that they'll come out with an extended edition DVD which might flesh things out a bit, giving these new plot elements more context.If you're a long-time Narnia fan, you'll probably want to check this movie out at some point.  But if you do see it, be prepared for it going off in some very odd directions.
summary: (3-1/2 Stars) What's With The Green Mist And The Swords?

reviewText: After literally falling asleep during TRON yesterday, VOYAGE OF THE DAWN TREADER really seemed fun and enjoyable.  The tone of 2010's movies has been oppressive - IRON MAN's depressed hero, HARRY POTTER's death count, TRON . . . just dark and dreary all around . . .This one, conversely, was sunshine, fun, adventure, with no weighty subject matter, no death toll, no depression . . . just fun.But, it was by no means perfect.  The opening moves WAY too fast to get to Narnia and then to get the voyage on its way (all within about ten minutes).  The first two films took much more care to build up the plot.The young actors seem largely bored this time out, not trying at all to bring any life to their characters.  Georgie Henley (Lucy), who was the heart of the first two films, seems anxious to get past this one and on to bigger and better things.  Ditto, Skandar Keynes and Ben Barnes (Edmund and Caspian). Only newcomer Will Poulter (as the whiny Eustace) brings any strength of character, balancing out the otherwise dull performances with a very exuberant (albeit annoying at first) level of gravitas to his role.And the plot . . . the plot . . . hmm, well . . . not really so much a plot as a thin string upon which to hang a series of adventures.  The focus at first is to find the seven missing lords of Prince Caspian's newly restored kingdom.  But this seques into a quest to discover the source of, and eliminate a pesky Green Mist that has stolen away many of the inhabitants of one of the islands the crew visits. This technically constitutes a storyline, but there isn't anything resembling the central conflicts of the previous two films.But, these gripes are quickly put aside by those who are able to simply enjoy a fantastical and fun film.  The truth is, after about thirty minutes, I no longer cared about the rushed opening and lack of solid performances or storyline, and simply enjoyed the grandiose effects, fanciful encounters (loved the invisible gnomes)and an awesome grand finale that gives the viewer the sailor-vs-sea beast battle that PIRATES OF THE CARRIBBEAN 3 robbed us of!As long as you can prepare your mind for this being less epic than the previous entries, and understand it is going to be more of a popcorn-munching series of adventures, you can really find a lot to enjoy in this third installment!

reviewText: Any cinematic adaptation of a popular literary work must find a balance between hewing to the book and appealing to moviegoers. The stakes in this case are well-known: the fate of the Narnia franchise depended on Voyage of the Dawn Treader's box office take. In order to appeal to the largest and most reliable crowd--families with young children--the screenwriters had to keep the plot fast and simple enough to ensure that kids wouldn't get confused or bored. The Voyage of the Dawn Treader is more challenging to adapt than other books in the series because of its lack of an obvious conflict and its episodic, slow-and-go narrative. For the film, the writers added an enemy (green mist), merged several book scenes, and changed the order of events to create a buildup of dramatic tension that wasn't in the book. Aside from the contrived Green Mist archenemy, I think they did a very good job.I evaluate this movie primarily as a grownup who enjoys the entire series of books, Dawn Treader most of all. To me, the first of Peter Jackson's Lord of the Rings films is the standard for cinematic adaptations of classic fantasy literature. Its acting, writing, and cinematography did justice to the spirit and content of the original work.As I watched Voyage of the Dawn Treader I couldn't shake the impression that all the characters were being carried along by a story in a rush to be completed under two hours and under budget. There were no lingering silences, few moments in which a facial expression or a tone of voice were given time to add texture and emphasis to a line of dialogue. Cameras that were usually zoomed in on characters' faces and upper bodies amplified the dearth of nuance. I believe that wider angles sometimes and more inclusion of the very pretty backgrounds would have mitigated.Character development was uneven. Edmund and King Caspian, whose motives and conflicts were wholly internal, got short shrift on screen. Lucy, Eustace, and Reepicheep evolved naturally and believably. Georgie Henley, Skandar Keynes and Ben Barnes demonstrated better acting ability in the earlier movies, so perhaps they and the director were hindered by time constraints and the cut-to-chase script. That rushed script also forced the morality lessons to be more plainly presented in the film than in the book, though they were not the Sunday school lectures some had feared. Aside from the Green Mist, the questionable camera work, and the rush over nuance in exposition, Voyage of the Dawn Treader excelled.The bond between Eustace and Reepicheep was lovingly and faithfully depicted and developed, and their respective Dragon and Mouse were rendered beautifully in CGI. Aslan, with his lush mane and Liam Neeson voice, inspired awe in every second he appeared. Scenes and backgrounds looked at once convincing and fantastic. The final battle at sea was as intense and dynamic as any from Pirates of the Caribbean.The film falls far short of Lord of the Rings overall, therefore I feel lukewarm about it as an adult filmgoer.Because I believe, however, that almost any elementary school age child would overlook Voyage of the Dawn Treader's flaws while being dazzled by its charms, I wholeheartedly endorse this film for children.Here's hoping that The Silver Chair makes it to the big screen, and gives viewers no less than a two hour escape to Narnia.
summary: Five stars for the kids. Adult fans? Two, maybe three.

reviewText: I prefer the 1980's BBC versions I grew up with from PBS.  At least they got the storylines mostly right!  The whole point of the Voyage of the Dawn Treader is for the 7 lost lords who were great friends of Caspian's father and banished by evil uncle Miraz to be found and for Caspian to venture to the farthest Eastern end of the world. Telemarines has been afraid of the water and the East because of Aslan, so Caspian is trying to make Narnia a seafaring nation again with this revolutionary voyage.  Some people say this book isn't exciting enough for a full-length feature film.  Oh, ok, I see, so being kidnapped by slavers and reconquering the Lone Islands, running across an island belonging to a fallen star and inhabited by invisible, one-footed beings, a fight over an island where the water turns anything to gold, being lost and becoming a dragon only to be turned human again when a lesson is learned, meeting a star at rest who eats a berry from the sun every morning, encountering a sea serpent, coming to an island where nightmares come true, and coming to the edge of the world isn't exciting enough???  This was my favorite book of the series growing up!Why, oh WHY was there this absolute B.S. about a green mist, people disappearing in boats as sacrifices, 7 swords beings united, etc etc???  Why did the story need it?  It felt tacked-on to me.  So many of my favorite scenes were forever fatally skewed and destroyed by this interpretation.  This was not The Voyage of the Dawn Treader, it was another story entirely that was vaguely based on said book.  Kids are too easily bored these days if the grand seafaring adventure the book was isn't enough for them.Here are all the things this movie got wrong:1.) Governor Gumpas isn't present at all, Lord Bern is in a dungeon, and we see the advent of the ridiculous "Green mist." What really happens is: Upon reaching the Lone Islands, Caspian, Eustace, Edmund, Lucy, and Reepicheep set across an empty island. They are all captured by slavers and taken to market.  Caspian is rescued by Lorn Bern who married a local girl and settled in the islands after leaving his companions to go on. They raise a small army and use a clever set of maneuvers to fool the idiot Governor Gumpas into believing Caspian has come to re-conquer the islands.  Gumpas is unseated and Bern is made a Duke.2.) The island of Coriakin comes WAY too soon! It belongs WAY further along in the series, after Eustace becomes good, before the encounter with the sea serpent.  Lucy isn't kidnapped, ever. She sees their footprints first and hears them, runs to her group, the whole group is surrounded after they see the house, lands, orchards, etc.  They are wined and dined and Lucy volunteers to undo the invisibility spell to keep her comrades safe. She sees the beauty spell but Aslan talks to her and she leaves it alone, she NEVER steals it! She makes friends with the fallen star (the movie never mentions he's a fallen star and caring for the Dufflepuds is his atonement) and he gives them guidance for the rest of their journey.  Again, NO GREEN MIST!!!3.) In the REAL story: The calm comes when Eustace is still a rotten kid.  He steals water, Reepicheep catches him.  Reepicheep later gets to go at him with a sword because Eustace pulled his tail while he was on lookout from the mouth of the dragon.4.) Deathwater Island and the Dragon Island are NOT the same thing!  In the book: The group camps out early on at the island of the dragon. Eustace wanders off, sees a dragon, sees the dragon die, finds the treasure in a cave, falls asleep, becomes a dragon.  He's terrified at first until he realizes he's the dragon.  Then he comes onto the beach, is challenged, then Lucy realizes who it is.  He finds how lonely he is as a dragon.  They spend many days on the island repairing the ship after the terrible storms they encountered.  See, they are tossed about in a tempest for days on end, the water supply runs low, they make it to the island, Eustace becomes a dragon and finds how fulfilling it is to be useful and have companionship.  Then Aslan comes to him and takes him to a pool where he keeps scraping several skins off himself until Aslan splits his skin deep and throws him into the pool.  Eustace is a boy again and a better one after he realizes how rotten he'd been before and how much he liked being nice and people being nice to him in return.  The bracelet Eustace wore the entire time proves the dragon he saw die was probably the lost Lord Octesian.  Eustace NEVER leaves the island as a dragon!! They know he could never ride on the ship or have the strength to fly.  Ridiculous.5.) At Deathwater Island, they find what they think is a statue, but realize when a shell is dipped into the water that he was once human. Remaining clothing and gear prove him to be Lord Restimar.  Caspian and Edmund fight as the thought of endless riches has a dangerously intoxicating effect, until Aslan interferes and speaks to both of them in their minds. They leave the island, never revealing its terrible secret. There is never a rivalry between Caspian and Edmund over who is the higher king.6.) The sea serpent wasn't part of Edmund's imagination, it was REAL.  It really did attack the ship and try to squeeze it in two.  It was only defeated by the efforts of everyone on the ship.  It was pushed over the stern of the ship and they sailed away before it could get its wits about it and come back to attack again.7.) The dark island is, yes, where they found Lord Rhoop.  But, it was not the source of some overpowering evil!  It was simply a place where nightmares came true.  It was a dark place in the ocean.  They sailed in when none of them wanted to be called cowards by Reepicheep for avoiding a possible adventure, found Lord Rhoop who was mad with years of residing there, were lured by the idea of dreams coming true, found out they were really nightmares, and then found they could not get out. An albatross came and led them out when Lucy called to Aslan for help. The island was destroyed in the process.8.) The Island of Ramandu was NOT as early as the movie made it! It was the last island before Aslan's country.  The crew actually meets Ramandu, who tells them he is a star at rest.  The story of the fireberries from the sun, and the birds that bring them, how the food is renewed every day, and how Ramandu will rise again as a new star, is SO beautiful! They left ALL of that out!  Awful!! They find the remaining 3 lost Lords, asleep at the table for years because they had fought about staying or continuing on, and one had picked up the stone knife that was used by the White Witch to kill Aslan in The Lion, The Witch, and The Wardrobe.  Before Ramandu's daughter explains this, they are speculating and think the food is to blame.  The the daughter explains that to wake the lords, they must sail as far East as their ship can take them, then leave at least one passenger behind.  Then Caspian (who has been looking for a wife but unable to find one he cars for) alludes to the tale of Sleeping Beauty and promises Ramandu's daughter that he will return for her. The crew nearly mutinies at the idea of carrying on, but Caspian manages to get all but one on board.9.) In the book: They sail on, the sun gets brighter, and they find they are caught in water they assume is forever rushing to the edge of the world and beyond it. They fear they may all be washed up and crash over the edge, but then find it is a broad channel they can steer out of if they wish onto calm water.  Lucy sees people who live under the sea, and their forests and castles.  Reepicheep tries to challenge one of them and falls into the water.  It is here he discovers the water is sweet, just like in the song the dryad sang over him as a baby.  They know they are near Aslan's country. A great lake of lilies grows for miles and miles, and they drink the sweet water to strengthen their eyes against the growing strength of the sun. The beauty is that they are getting nearer and nearer the sun the whole time, and daily they see the birds flying to Ramandu's Island to grant him youth and renew the feast.  Another beautiful part that was LEFT OUT!!10.) The Dawn Treader doesn't dump Caspian, Edmund, Lucy, Eustace, and Reepicheep in the boat to find their way to a sandbar where Aslan is!  Really, it sails until it can sail no longer. Caspian then declares he will be the one left behind to find himself in Aslan's Country. He gets in a fight with Drinian, Edmund, and Lucy then storms into his cabin. There, Aslan talks to him, and he comes back to say he sees now that he must return to rule his country and take Ramandu's daughter as a bride.  Aslan tells him Edmund, Lucy, Eustace, and Reepicheep must continue on, as Reepicheep wishes to partake in the biggest adventure of all.  They go to a spit of land where Aslan greets them and tells Edmund and Lucy they cannot return to Narnia.  Reepicheep gives up his sword, and continues on in his little coracle. The three children are returned to the bedroom where it all started and are great friends afterwards.At least the movie got the beginning and ending right, but that's about it.  All the other events are so out of sequence, mixed together, or changed in some integral way that I cannot appreciate the movie for what it is.  Too many things that were dear to me were changed too much.  I can't enjoy it for what it is.  Through the whole thing, all I could think was "that didn't happen!" and "that's now how/when that happened!"Screenwriters: stop messing with classics!  These are classics for a reason, beloved for decades for a REASON!  Why do you think you can improve on something so well-loved already?  Why do you think your ideas are better or more exciting?  These books will remain classics for many, many years to come, while these interpretations fade into obscurity.  The reason Prince Caspian and The Voyage of the Dawn Treader weren't great successes is because you CHANGED them too much!!!  Can't you see that??Bottom line: Change is NOT always a good thing!!!
summary: Take a childhood classic, scramble it up, dump in some dumb story ideas and you have this movie.

reviewText: "The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader," the third installment of the saga, follows the adventures of Lucy (Georgie Henley) and Edmund (Skandar Keynes), two youngest Pevensie children summoned once again to the world of Narnia, this time with their sulky cousin Eustace Scrubb (Will Poulter) in tow. Lucy and Edmund reunite with Prince Caspian (Ben Barnes) and a sword-wielding warrior mouse Reepicheep (voice Simon Pegg replacing Eddie Izzard), they set forth to brave the dangers of unknown seas in order to find the secrets of the seven missing lords of Narnia and the mysterious green mist.Even if you haven't read the C.S. Lewis's original books (I only read "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe"), you will notice there have been changes done to the story. The film adaptation is action-packed, but feels rather lengthy in the mid-section. Character development is shown - Lucy is tempted by her own desire, and Eustace literally undergoes transformation - but not enough, and the process is not very convincing. Two male characters Caspian and Edmund are almost unmemorable throughout.Still, "The Voyage of the Dawn Treader" has impressive production designs (such as the titular ship) and the visual effects including one rousing battle scene. But probably the film's best part would be its moving ending, which defines the entire third installment. Without spoiling too much, I can say it is time to say good-bye. It has been five years since the first "Narnia" was released, in which Lucy found a lamppost behind the old wardrobe and met Mr. Tumnus. Time has passed very quickly.Narnia looks less magical than it used to (or should) be, perhaps because we have seen so many fantasy movies made recently. Still "The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader" is an entertaining family picture with gorgeous visuals and thrilling actions.
summary: (3.5 STARS) Flawed, But Still Entertaining Family Picture

reviewText: I recently watched the movie version of Lewis's book The Voyage of the Dawn Treader.  I left entertained but not satisfied; so I decided to read the book again, which is my favorite in the series.  After finishing, I see three reasons that the movies fall short of the books.First, there is a literary error.  The moviemakers appear to understand the books as children's adventure stories with a spiritual twist.  This causes them to make the films into family-friendly action-adventure flicks.  One wonders how they will be able to handle the increasingly mature themes in the later books.This leads them to put their cinematographic efforts into battles and miss the opportunity to rise up to the creative challenge of putting into pictures Lewis's vivid portrayals of spiritual truths and experiences.The result is that the scenes with Aslan or those that broach the spiritual dimension seem anemic.These errors affect negatively the movie version of The Voyage of the Dawn Treader.  Three scenes or themes fail to live up to the book.  Consequently, a potentially classic children's movie of spiritual import becomes just a forgettable, albeit enjoyable, action-adventure movie.The first failure is Eustace's transformation from a dragon back into a boy.  Now, the movie does capture the delightfully nasty Eustace quite well, but its portrayal of Aslan the lion pawing the ground to remove the dragon skin from Eustace is tepid.  In the book the transformation is brutally vivid.  Eustace the dragon actually removes three layers of skin before Aslan has to take over.  When Aslan does, his claws tear so deeply that Eustace feels as if the lion has cut into his heart.  The book paints a striking picture of our inability to remove sin and the need for Christ to remove it.  Was it thought that the book is too graphic for a "family" movie?The second failure is the dark island where everyone's dreams come true.  The movie pulls out all stops to create an exciting fight against a sea serpent, but this is child's play in comparison to the horrific imaginative possibilities of Lewis's writing.  In the book, while the crew in panic desperately tries to row out of the darkness after being warned that it is a place of nightmares, those nightmares begin to take form.  They hear unnamed creatures crawling up the sides of the ship, see something on the mast and hear the sound of scissors opening and closing and are unable to find their way out of the darkness.  In answer to Lucy's prayer Aslan comes as an albatross and leads them to the light.  One experiences powerfully the relief of being delivered from a nightmare.  Surely with our technology this is a scene that the movie could have captured for us.  Were they too afraid of frightening children to use all the techniques of horror films to show us a nightmare?However, the movie's greatest failure is not being able to portray the main element of the story--sailing to the world's end and Aslan's land.  It starts badly. One can barely hear Reepicheep's recital of the dryad's words over his cradle about finding all he'd seek where sky and water meet.  And nowhere in the film does one catch Reepicheep's passionate longing to sail east in the Dawn Treader, and, when she fails, to paddle east in his coracle, when it sinks to swim east with his four paws, and, when he can swim no longer and hasn't reached Aslan's land or plunged over a cataract at the world's end, to sink with his nose to the sunrise.Lewis is a visual author and the last chapters of The Voyage of the Dawn Treader are perhaps his best.  It is a shame that the makers of the movie did not use all the marvelous cinematic techniques to allow us to see Lewis's magical mystical descriptions of the end of the voyage.  What a joy it would have been to experience vicariously via film the crew's journey into the sun with shining faces, drinking liquid light while sailing through the whiteness of the Silver Sea of lilies shot with gold.This is Lewis's fictional portrayal of "joy," that sweet longing for something that is always just out of our grasp in this world.  This was the central experience used to bring him to God.  For this reason The Voyage of the Dawn Treader takes the form of a quest, like the search for the Holy Grail.  This is the great adventure.While rereading those wonderful pages, my heart was filled to overflowing, and, when Reepicheep disappeared over the great wave, I burst into tears and cried out as I thought of my sins, for I am a Calvinist, "I have wasted my inheritance for a mess of pottage."  At the end of the book I was made ready to return to the real world after supping by the seashore with the Lamb, who is the Lion.  It was not just an evening's entertainment.  Please, read the book if you haven't.
summary: What's Wrong with The Narnia Movies?
